reference.title: Entities
reference.shortdesc: This file contains entities that must be used in the DITA source files.

section.title: Product-name entities
section.p:

devices that run

Backend Read Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) that were transferred for read operations.
Backend Write Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) that were transferred for write operations.
Total Backend Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) that were transferred for read and write operations.
Backend Read I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second for read operations.
Total Backend I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second for read and write operations.
Backend Write I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second for write operations.
Backend Read Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to respond to each read operation. For models, this time is the external response time of the managed disks (MDisks).
Backend Write Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to respond to each write operation. For models, this time is the external response time of the managed disks (MDisks).
Overall Backend Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to respond to each I/O operation (read and write). For models, this time is the external response time of the managed disks (MDisks).
Write-cache Delay Percentage

Percentage of I/O operations that were delayed because of write-cache space constraints or other conditions. Write-cache Delay Percentage is the ratio of delayed I/O operations to total I/O operations.
NVS Delayed I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second that were delayed because of nonvolatile storage (NVS) space constraints.
Interval

Size of the sample interval (in seconds). For , , , , and models, you can specify a minimum interval length of five minutes and a maximum interval length of one hour. For models, you can specify a minimum interval length of 15 minutes and a maximum interval length of one hour.
Overall Read Cache %
Overall read cache percentage for both sequential and nonsequential read operations.
Read I/O Rate (overall)
Average number of I/O operations per second for both sequential and non-sequential read operations for a component over a specified time interval.
Overall Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to service each I/O operation (read and write) for a component over a specified time interval.
Return Codes
Overall Write Cache %
Percentage of cache hits for both sequential and nonsequential write operations.
Write I/O Rate (overall)
Average number of I/O operations per second for both sequential and non-sequential write operations for a component over a specified time interval.
other storage systems
Read Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for read operations for a component over a specified time interval.
Read Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to service each read operation for a component over a specified time interval.
Sequential I/O Percentage
Percentage of all I/O operations that are performed for an array over a specified time interval that were sequential operations.
Subsystem
ID of the storage system
Time
Date and time that the data was collected.
Total Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for read and write operations for a component over a specified time interval.
Total Overall Cache %
Percentage of cache hits for both sequential and nonsequential read and write operations.
Total I/O Rate (overall)
Average number of I/O operations per second for both sequential and nonsequential read and write operations.
Total Response Time
Write Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for write operations for a component over a specified time interval.
Write Response Time
Average number of milliseconds that it took to service each write operation for a component over a specified time interval.
Peak Read Response Time
The peak (worst) response time for disk reads for a component over a time interval.
Peak Write Response Time
The peak (worst) response time for disk writes for a component over a time interval.

section.title: K's working entities

p.ph: This page is displayed only if is installed. You can create a new zone for the ports or add them to an existing zone. Use a Zone Action if you want to apply updates to the active zone set. This action applies changes to the inactive zone set that has the same name as the active zone set and then the zone set is activated. Before you use this option, ensure that the zones and zone members in the active zone set matches the zones and zone members in the inactive zone that is set with the same name.

section.p:
Type of subsystem:
DS6000
DS8000
ESS
FAStT
SVC

Status of the subsystem:
Normal
Warning
Unreachable

dlentry.dd: The ID who created the schedule or alert.
The name of the schedule or alert. The ID of the user is automatically attached to the name as a prefix. For example, if you name a schedule "dailyprobe", saves the name as "TPCUser.dailyprobe".
The description of the schedule or alert.
Select this option to activate the schedule or alert. If this option is not selected, the schedule or alert does not run.
Export this alert to an external application that can use the data. To be exported, an alert must relate to a volume mapped to the external application. By default, this option is not selected.
Select this option to generate an SNMP trap message to any NMS, console, or terminal to indicate the occurrence of an alert.

Select this option to send the alert to the Tivoli Event Console (TEC) or OMNIbus EIF probe server. The TEC administrator can write correlation and automation rules to analyze events and perform responses such as send further notification, create or update trouble tickets, and run programs.
Select this option to indicate alerts must display to the specified user upon logging in to user interface.
Indicate the ID of the user to receive alert notifications upon logging in to the system.
Select this option to record alerts in the OS Event Log.
Indicate the type of event to record in the Windows Event Log.
Indicate where the UNIX Syslog is sent. You can select User or Local.
Select the level of UNIX Syslog event. You can select Informational, Notice, Warning, Error, Critical, or Alert.
Select this option to run a script in response to this alert. Click Define to specify a script to run and the computer on which it must run.

Select this option to send alert notifications to the specified email addresses. The following fields become active when you select this option:
Email Recipients You can view, add, and delete email addresses for the alert notification. Use the first box in the section to enter the email addresses you want to include for the alert notification. The box that follows displays the email addresses already associated with the alert notification.
Add Click this button to add an email address you entered in the Email Recipients field.
Del Click this button to delete the email address you highlighted in the Email Recipients list box.
Edit email Click this button to edit the text of the email alert notification on the Edit Text of the email Message panel.

section.note: You must have Fabric administrator authority to perform fabric-control tasks.

dlentry.dd: Click to create a new zone. In the Zone name field, type the name of the new zone. The ports that are listed in the field that follows are added to the new zone.
Click to update an existing zone; then, select a zone. The ports that are listed in the field that follows are added to the selected zone.
Click to avoid performing any fabric-control tasks. The ports that are listed in the field that follows are not able to communicate with the subsystem on this fabric.

li.ph: Agent Name

For space-efficient volumes, this value is the amount of storage space that is requested for these volumes, not the actual allocated amount. This value can result in discrepancies in the overall storage space reported for a storage system that uses space-efficient volumes. This situation also applies to other space calculations, such as the calculations for the storage system's Consumable (Available) Volume Space and FlashCopy Target Volume Space.

Name of the agent on the host system that has HBA with the same Port WWN installed. This field is blank if there is not an agent that is installed on a host system that has HBA with the same Port WWN installed.
Agent Network Address
The fully qualified network name of the agent.
Agent OS Type
Operating system of the computer on which the agent is deployed.
Disk Capacity
OS disk capacity of the volume.
Disk Path
Name of the disk as assigned by the operating system.
HBA Port WWN
worldwide name of the HBA port to which the volume is assigned.
Volume Format

Indicates the format of the storage volume. The valid values are: Unknown, Fixed Block, Block 512, Block 520 Protected, Block 520 Unprotected, 3380, 3390, 3390 Extended, Count Key Data. The mainframe volumes are identified as 3380, 3390, 3390 Extended, or Count Key Data.
Volume WWN
WWN (worldwide name) is an identifier that uniquely identifies a volume, as assigned by the storage system.
Physical Allocation
Total amount of disk space that is consumed (overhead + capacity). This amount includes the capacity that is obtained by VDisk copies.
Probe Last Run
Date and time when the storage subsystem was last probed.
Serial Number
Serial number of a disk.
SMIS Host Alias
Alias name of the host (computer name) to which the volume is assigned. This name might be different from the name of the agent because users can customize the host name.
Storage Subsystem Type
Type of storage subsystem, such as the IBM SAN Volume Controller.
Unallocated Volume Space
Volume capacity that is assigned to each computer minus the space that is allocated to a logical volume.
WWN Match

Indicates Yes if an agent is installed on the host system and was able to match the HBA Port WWN that was returned by a storage subsystem probe job. This column displays a value for: Windows, Solaris, and HP-UX systems if the HBA API client is installed on the host agent.
Free Space
Amount of storage space that is available.
Volume Capacity
Storage capacity that is on a volume.
Volume Name (disk array)
Name that is assigned to a volume by a storage subsystem. For , or DS5000, it is the user-created name.
Volume Name
Name that is assigned to a volume.
Capacity
Total usable storage capacity of a volume.

dlentry.dd: Lists the information columns that can be included in the report. The available columns are based on what you select in the Relate File Systems/Logical Volumes To field.
Lists the information columns that are included in the report.
Lists the information columns that can be included in the report.
Lists the information columns that are included in the report.
Click this button to generate the report.

section.title: New report column entities added by Rick - WI214 - Storage Subsystem Performance by SVC Node

li.ph: Node
The ID of the specified node.
Read Cache Hits Percentage (overall)
Percentage of cache hits for both sequential and nonsequential read operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Write Cache Hits Percentage (overall)
Percentage of cache hits for both sequential and nonsequential write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Total Cache Hits Percentage (overall)
Percentage of cache hits for both sequential and nonsequential read and write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Read Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for read operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Write Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Overall Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for read and write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Disk to Cache Transfer Rate
Average number of I/O operations (track transfers) per second for disk to cache transfers, for a particular component over an interval.
Cache to Disk Transfer Rate
Average number of I/O operations (track transfers) per second for cache to disk transfers, for a particular component over an interval.
Write-cache Delay Percentage

Percentage of I/O operations that were delayed because of write-cache space constraints or other conditions, for a particular component over an interval. (The ratio of delayed operations to total I/Os.)
Write-cache Delay I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second that were delayed because of write-cache space constraints or other conditions, for a particular component over an interval.
Read Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each read operation waited on the queue before it is issued to the back-end device, for a particular MDisk or MDisk Group over an interval.
Write Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each write operation waited on the queue before it is issued to the back-end device, for a particular MDisk or MDisk Group over an interval.
Overall Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each read and write operation that is waited on the queue before it is issued to the back-end device, for a particular MDisk or MDisk Group over an interval.
Backend Read Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for read operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Backend Write Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Overall Backend Transfer Size
Average number of KB per I/O for read and write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Port Send I/O Rate
Average number of KB per I/O for read and write operations, for a particular component over an interval.
Port Receive I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second for receive operations, for a particular port over an interval.
Total Port I/O Rate
Average number of I/O operations per second for send and receive operations, for a particular port over an interval.
Port Send Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for send (write) operations, for a particular port over an interval.
Port Receive Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for receive (read) operations, for a particular port over an interval.
Total Port Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second that were transferred for send and receive operations, for a particular port over an interval.
Readahead Percentage of Cache Hits
Percentage of all read cache hits, which occurred on prestaged data.
Write-cache Overflow Percentage
Percentage of write operations that were delayed because of lack of write-cache space, for a particular component over an interval.
Write-cache Overflow I/O Rate
Average number of tracks per second that were delayed because of lack of write-cache space, for a particular component over an interval.
Write-cache Flush-through Percentage
Percentage of write operations that were processed in flush-through write mode, for a particular component over an interval.
Write Cache Flush-through I/O Rate
Average number of tracks per second that were processed in flush-through write mode, for a particular component over an interval.
Write Cache Write-through Percentage
Percentage of write operations that were processed in write-through write mode, for a particular component over an interval.
Write Cache Write-through I/O Rate
Average number of tracks per second that were processed in write-through write mode, for a particular component over an interval.
Dirty Write Percentage of Cache Hits
Percentage of all write cache hits, which occurred on already dirty data in the cache.
CPU Utilization Percentage
Average utilization percentage of the CPU(s) for a particular component over an interval.
Port to Host Send I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second sent to host computers by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Host Receive I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second received from host computers by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Host I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second transmitted between host computers and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Disk Send I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second sent to storage subsystems by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Disk Receive I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second received from storage subsystems by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Disk I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second transmitted between storage subsystems and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Send I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second sent to other nodes in the local SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Receive I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second received from other nodes in the local SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Local Node I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second transmitted between other nodes in the local SVC cluster and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Send I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second sent to nodes in the remote SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Receive I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second received from nodes in the remote SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Remote Node I/O Rate
Average number of exchanges (I/Os) per second transmitted between nodes in the remote SVC cluster and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Host Send Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second sent to host computers by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Host Receive Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second received from host computers by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Host Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second transmitted between host computers and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Disk Send Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second sent to storage subsystems by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Disk Receive Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second received from storage subsystems by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Disk Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second transmitted between storage subsystems and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Send Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second sent to other nodes in the local SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Receive Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second received from other nodes in the local SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Local Node Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second transmitted between other nodes in the local SVC cluster and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Send Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second sent to nodes in the remote SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Receive Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second received from nodes in the remote SVC cluster by a particular component over an interval.
Total Port to Remote Node Data Rate
Average number of megabytes (2^20 bytes) per second transmitted between nodes in the remote SVC cluster and a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Send Response Time
Average number of milliseconds to service each send operation, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Port to Local Node Receive Response Time
Average number of milliseconds to service all receive operations, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Overall Port to Local Node Response Time
Average number of milliseconds to service all send and receive operations, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Port to Local Node Send Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each send operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Port to Local Node Receive Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each receive operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Overall Port to Local Node Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Send Response Time
Average number of milliseconds it took to service each send operation, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Port to Remote Node Receive Response Time
Average number of milliseconds it took to service all receive operations, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Overall Port to Remote Node Response Time
Average number of milliseconds it took to service all send and receive operations, for a particular component over an interval. For SVC, this time is the external response time of the transfers.
Port to Remote Node Send Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each send operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Port to Remote Node Receive Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each receive operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Overall Port to Remote Node Queue Time
Average number of milliseconds that each operation waits on the queue before it is issued, for a particular component over an interval.
Global Mirror Write I/O Rate
Average number of write operations per second issued to the Global Mirror secondary site.
Global Mirror Overlapping Write Percentage
Average percentage of write operations that are issued to the Global Mirror secondary site, which were overlapping writes.
Global Mirror Overlapping Write I/O Rate
Average number of overlapping write operations per second encountered by the Global Mirror primary site.
Read Cache Size
Amount of read cache, in KB, that was in use for a particular component, at the start of the particular interval.
Write Cache Size
Amount of write cache, in KB, that was in use for a particular component, at the start of the particular interval.

section.title: Changing entity names
section.p:
Some entities do not provide unique, recognizable names when they are discovered or probed. This action can result in duplicate entity names in the topology or in report selection lists. To change the name of an entity, follow these steps.
Right-click the entity in the topology.
In the menu, select Launch details panel.
In the Label field, enter the new name for the entity.
Click Save to save the new name.

section.title: Data Path Explorer items added by Sue Norris 8/22/07
Analyze tiering, balancing pools, and transforming volumes wizards

dlentry.dd: The activity level of the pool. The value for the activity level of the pool is estimated based on the performance data that was collected on the previous day or over the period that was specified by the user.
The projected activity level of the pool when the recommendations are implemented.

The difference in percent between the activity level of the pool and the average activity level of all of the pools on the same tier and in the same storage system. A positive deviation value indicates that the pool has an above average activity level in relation to other pools on the same tier. A negative deviation value indicates that the pool has a below average activity level in relation to other pools on the same tier.
The projected activity deviation % of the pool when the recommendations are implemented.

p.note: On the Pools page, the activity level of the pool is shown in the Activity column. The difference between the activity level of the pool and all of the other pools on the same tier and storage system is shown in the Activity Deviation (%) column.

Why not create a dedicated user account to manage the monitoring of your storage systems more efficiently? So, instead of using an existing user account, create a new user account to connect to and collect metadata from your storage resources.

section.title: What "IBM Spectrum Virtualized" is used to refer to

p.ph: The following storage systems run to virtualize their storage: , , , , , , , , , and .
In this documentation, is used to refer collectively to , , , and storage systems, and to devices that run .
